International agreements do not change this, EU laws implementing international agreements have to be compatible with the EU Treaties as well. The EU Treaties establish a complete system of legal remedies and procedures, the EU Court of Justice (ECJ) has exclusive competence to review the lawfulness of EU acts. Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement creates a parallel track. It falls outside the complete system of legal remedies established by the EU Treaties and conflicts with the ECJ&#8217;s exclusive competence. Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement is not compatible with the EU Treaties, it undermines the very foundations of the Union.</em></p> <p><strong>Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement</strong></p> <p>Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement clauses in international agreements give multinationals the right to sue states for international arbitration tribunals and demand high damages. In recent years, arbitration tribunals increasingly stretched the concept of expropriation. Multinationals can now sue states if legislative changes may make their profits lower than expected, even if the legislative changes are needed for the public interest, like protecting health. This puts pressure on the democratic process and the public interest.</p> <p><strong>International tribunals above high courts</strong></p> <p>Tobacco company Philip Morris sued Australia over the Tobacco Plain Packaging Bill, which introduced restrictions on the use of cigarette company&#8217;s logos on cigarette packets and allow for more space for health warnings. After Australia&#8217;s High Court dismissed the legal challenge, Philip Morris launched an investor-state case, bypassing Australia&#8217;s High Court. As a result, Australia decided not to sign treaties with investor-state arbitration clauses any more.</p> <p>Using investor &#8211; state dispute settlement to bypass local courts, including the highest court, raises the question whether the EU Treaties allow arbitration to bypass the European Court of Justice when it comes to the interpretation of the EU Treaties.</p> <p><strong>ECJ case law: Kadi et al</strong></p> <p>The Treaties establish a complete system of legal remedies and procedures, the lawfulness of EU acts is for the Court to review. Some quotes from Joint Cases C-402/05 P, Kadi et al, and C-415/05 P (emphasis added).</p> <p>In paragraph 281 the Court considers that &#8220;it is to be borne in mind that the Community is based on the rule of law, inasmuch as neither its Member States nor its institutions can avoid review of the conformity of their acts with the basic constitutional charter, the EC Treaty, which established a <em>complete system of legal remedies and procedures</em> designed to enable the Court of Justice to <em>review the legality of acts of the institutions</em> (Case 294/83 Les Verts v Parliament [1986] ECR 1339, paragraph 23).&#8221;</p> <p>In paragraph 282 the Court recalls &#8220;that an international agreement cannot affect the allocation of powers fixed by the Treaties or, consequently, the <em>autonomy of the Community legal system</em>, observance of which is <em>ensured by the Court</em> by virtue of the <em>exclusive jurisdiction</em> conferred on it by Article 220 EC, jurisdiction that the Court has, moreover, already held to form part of the <em>very foundations of the Community</em> (see, to that effect, Opinion 1/91 [1991] ECR I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd6079, paragraphs 35 and 71, and Case C-459/03 Commission v Ireland [2006] ECR I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd4635, paragraph 123 and case-law cited).&#8221;</p> <p>In paragraphs 283 and 284 the Court considers that <em>fundamental rights</em> form an integral part of the general principles of law and that respect for human rights is a condition of the lawfulness of Community acts.</p> <p>In paragraph 285 the Court considers: &#8220;It follows from all those considerations that the obligations imposed by an <em>international agreement cannot have the effect of prejudicing the constitutional principles of the EC Treaty</em>, which include the principle that all Community acts must respect <em>fundamental rights</em>, that respect constituting a condition of their lawfulness which it is for the Court to review in the framework of the complete system of legal remedies established by the Treaty.&#8221;</p> <p><strong>ISDS outside the complete system of legal remedies and procedures</strong></p> <p>Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement falls outside the complete system of legal remedies and procedures established by the EU Treaties. Arbitration tribunals will not request the ECJ preliminary rulings on the interpretation of Union law or on the validity of acts adopted by the institutions. They will decide themselves on the validity of acts adopted by the institutions. The ECJ and arbitration tribunals may reach different conclusions.</p> <p>An investor may dislike EU legislation safeguarding a human right, say access to medicine, and state that it is not compatible with an international agreement ratified by the EU. The ECJ may consider that the international agreement can not take away the Union&#8217;s legislative space to safeguard human rights and dismiss the legal challenge.</p> <p>The investor may then launch an investor &#8211; EU case. The tribunals may assume jurisdiction without taking into consideration the compatibility of investor-state arbitration with EU law. (Compare: Olivet, C, 2013) International arbitrators are not ordinarily well versed in human rights. (Kelsey and Wallach, 2012). The arbitration tribunal may find the EU law safeguarding a human right not compatible with the trade agreement. The decisions conflict.</p> <p>Investor &#8211; state dispute settlement undermines the autonomy of the Union&#8217;s legal system, the ECJ&#8217;s exclusive jurisdiction &#8211; a very foundation of the Union (compare paragraph 282 ECJ case Kadi et al, quoted above).</p> <p>ECJ, Joint Cases C-402/05 P, Kadi et al, and C-415/05 P, 2008,<br /> <a href="http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&#038;docid=67611&#038;pageIndex=0&#038;doclang=EN&#038;mode=lst&#038;dir=&#038;occ=first&#038;part=1&#038;cid=1560491">http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?text=&#038;docid=67611&#038;pageIndex=0&#038;doclang=EN&#038;mode=lst&#038;dir=&#038;occ=first&#038;part=1&#038;cid=1560491<br /> </a></p> <p>Kelsey and Wallach, 2012, &#8220;Investor-State&#8221; Disputes in Trade Pacts Threaten Fundamental Principles of National Judicial Systems,<br /> <a href="http://tpplegal.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/isds-domestic-legal-process-background-brief.pdf">http://tpplegal.files.wordpress.com/2012/05/isds-domestic-legal-process-background-brief.pdf<br /> </a></p> <p>Olivet, C, Transnational Institute, 2013, A test for European solidarity &#8211; The case of intra-EU Bilateral Investment Treaties <a href="http://www.tni.org/briefing/intra-eu-bilateral-investment-treaties-test-european-solidarity?context=70931">http://www.tni.org/briefing/intra-eu-bilateral-investment-treaties-test-european-solidarity?context=70931<br /> </a></p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">EU member states may not have a veto on TTIP / TAFTA</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1860"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1860</id>   <updated>2013-05-01T20:57:47+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>After the negotiations, the EU member states may not have a veto on the proposed trade agreement with the US (TTIP / TAFTA). </p> <p>I wrote earlier about some <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1773">issues with the EU draft mandate</a> for the EU \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd US trade agreement. </p> <p>In addition, I note that the draft TTIP mandate (<a href="http://www.s2bnetwork.org/fileadmin/dateien/downloads/EU_Draft_Mandate_-_Inside_US_Trade.pdf">pdf</a>) does not mention criminal measures. Criminal measures were the reason that the EU member states had a veto on ACTA (Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement). With ACTA, the member states negotiated the criminal measures. After the negotiations, the Commission proposed ACTA as a mixed agreement to Council and Parliament. A mixed agreement has to be ratified by the EU and the member states. This gives the national parliaments a strong position.</p> <p>The draft TTIP / TAFTA mandate notes about the negotiations that the Commission will negotiate, in consultation with the member states in the appropriate committee of the Council. No role for the member states in the negotiations itself.</p> <p>The consequence of this approach is that the Commission may, after the negotiations, exercise its competence, and make an EU only proposal for adoption by the Council (after consent by the Parliament). The Council shall decide with a qualified majority to ratify. No member states ratification is needed, no strong role for national parliaments. </p> <p>Basically, if the Commission negotiates some goodies for the German industry, and some goodies for some other big EU member states (having most votes in Council and Parliament), a majority for the proposed agreement is as good as certain, however bad it may be for the interests of smaller EU member states, for the public interest, democracy, access to medicine and human rights.   </p> <p>The mandate is very broad. If the Council authorises the Commission to negotiate, the smaller member states will have lost their grip on the outcome. They may like to take a good look at the mandate. </p> <p><strong>Unanimity</strong></p> <p>Mixed agreements have to be ratified by the EU and the member states, this gives national parliaments a strong position. They can crash an agreement by refusing to ratify. There is also an other kind of veto, but weaker.</p> <p>The Council decides by qualified majority. There are some exceptions for which unanimity in the Council is needed, see <a href="http://www.euwiki.org/TFEU#Article_207">art 207 TFEU</a>. While this implies a veto too, it is a less strong veto than the one a mixed agreement gives, as unanimity regards only limited areas, can be contested and a government may not listen to its parliament (may put a resolution aside) and vote in favour of an agreement in the Council even if its parliament is against it. (We saw such betrayal of national parliaments during the software patents directive proposal procedure.)</p> <p>Article 207(4):</p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;For the negotiation and conclusion of the agreements referred to in paragraph 3, the Council shall act by a qualified majority.</p> <p>For the negotiation and conclusion of agreements in the fields of trade in services and the commercial aspects of intellectual property, as well as foreign direct investment, the Council shall act unanimously where such agreements include provisions for which unanimity is required for the adoption of internal rules.</p> <p>The Council shall also act unanimously for the negotiation and conclusion of agreements:</p> <p>(a)in the field of trade in cultural and audiovisual services, where these agreements risk prejudicing the Union&#8217;s cultural and linguistic diversity;</p> <p>(b)in the field of trade in social, education and health services, where these agreements risk seriously disturbing the national organisation of such services and prejudicing the responsibility of Member States to deliver them. </p></blockquote> <p>The exceptions for which unanimity is needed regard the cultural exception (&#8220;cultural diversity&#8221; in the Treaties) France is concerned about. They also regard social, education and health services, but there may be a high threshold for unanimity (&#8220;risk seriously disturbing the national organisation of such services and prejudicing the responsibility of Member States to deliver them&#8221;). Regarding &#8220;commercial aspects of intellectual property&#8221;, that is not applicable here, as internal IP rules are normally adopted by qualified majority. The unanimity exceptions (TFEU 118 language arrangements and TFEU 262 confer jurisdiction) will not be part of the TTIP.</p> <p>(I leave trade in services and foreign direct investment to others.)</p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="fr">   <title type="html">Merci Donald Knuth</title>   <link href="http://renemages.wordpress.com/2013/05/01/merci-donald-knuth/"/>   <id>http://renemages.wordpress.com/?p=2948</id>   <updated>2013-04-30T23:13:22+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><a href="http://renemages.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/d_knuth_noticia.jpg"><img src="http://renemages.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/d_knuth_noticia.jpg?w=490&#038;h=325" alt="d_knuth_noticia" width="490" height="325" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2953" /></a></p> <blockquote> <p>&quot;Essayer d\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtablir une distinction entre des algorithmes math\ufffd\ufffdmatiques et des algorithmes non math\ufffd\ufffdmatiques n\ufffd\ufffd\ufffda aucun sens.&quot;</p> <p>&quot;Le Congr\ufffd\ufffds a sagement d\ufffd\ufffdcid\ufffd\ufffd il y a longtemps que les objets math\ufffd\ufffdmatiques ne pouvaient \ufffd\ufffdtre brevetables.   <entry>   <title type="html">EP trade committee rejects meaningful TTIP amendments</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1849"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1849</id>   <updated>2013-04-25T21:45:22+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Today the European Parliament International Trade committee voted on a draft resolution on the EU &#8211; US trade agreement (TTIP / TAFTA). La Quadrature du Net summarizes it: <a href="https://www.laquadrature.net/en/eu-parliament-opens-the-door-to-copyright-repression-in-tafta">EU Parliament Opens The Door to Copyright Repression in TAFTA</a>.</p> <p>The INTA committee could have voted meaningful amendments into the draft resolution, but declined to do that.</p> <p><strong>Intellectual property</strong></p> <p>The committee adopted this compromise amendment: </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;Stresses that intellectual property is one of the driving forces of innovation and creation and a pillar of the knowledge-based economy and that the agreement should include strong protection of precisely and clearly defined areas of intellectual property rights (IPR), including geographical indications, and be consistent with international agreements; believes that other areas of divergence in IPR should be solved in line with international standards of protection;&#8221; </p></blockquote> <p>The words &#8220;precisely and clearly defined areas of intellectual property rights&#8221; came from an amendment proposed by Marietje Schaake and Metin Kazak. The clearly defined areas are still to be defined&#8230;</p> <p>Schaake had proposed (some with other members of parliament) more amendments, which would have given guidance for the defining of areas. For instance amendment 121: </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;11a. Stresses that given the rejection of the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA), prompted by concerns about restrictions on digital freedoms and the open internet, online copyright enforcement, as well as intermediary liability, these measures should not be included or aimed at in the TTIP agreement, neither by explicitly binding provisions nor by introducing or committing to restrictive interpretation or implementation of relevant EU law;&#8221;</p></blockquote> <p>But those amendments didn&#8217;t make it, &#8220;precisely and clearly defined areas of intellectual property rights&#8221; ended up empty. </p> <p><strong>Openness</strong></p> <p>What happened with openness? Marietje Schaake and Metin Kazak proposed (amendment 176): </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;15. Recalls the need for continuous transparency, engagement with the stakeholders, including business, environmental, consumer, labour, civil liberties and other representatives, throughout the negotiation process, in order to ensure fact-based discussions, proportionate input from various sides and to foster public support;&#8221;</p></blockquote> <p>Continuous transparency (&#8230;) throughout the negotiation process, that is meaningful. Schaake and Kazak seem to have considered that there was no chance that the amendment would be adopted, they settled for compromise amendment 16: </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;Recalls the need for pro-active outreach and continuous and transparent engagement by the Commission with a wide range of stakeholders, including business, environmental, agricultural, consumer, labour and other representatives, throughout the negotiation process, in order to ensure fact-based discussions, build trust in the negotiations, obtain proportionate input from various sides and foster public support by taking stakeholders&#8217; concerns into consideration; encourages all stakeholders to actively participate and put forward initiatives and information relevant to the negotiations;&#8221;</p></blockquote> <p>Continuous transparency (&#8230;) throughout the negotiation process became transparent engagement by the Commission with a wide range of stakeholders. Here only the engagement by the Commission has to be transparent, that is meaningless&#8230;</p> <p>Thanks to La Quadrature du Net for sharing the compromise amendments (not published by the European Parliament) and the voting results with me. As the voting lists are not made public, the votes are very hard to follow, and as the compromise amendments are not published, the votes are impossible to follow. </p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">FFII letter to European Parliament Trade committee on agreement with US</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1836"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1836</id>   <updated>2013-04-22T08:43:59+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Today the FFII sent a letter to the European Parliament committee on International Trade. Thursday 25 April 2013 the committee will vote on <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1832">198 amendments to a draft resolution</a> on the EU &#8211; US trade agreement (TTIP / TAFTA)</p> <p><a href="http://people.ffii.org/~ante/ttip/ffii-inta-2013-04-22.pdf">Text as pdf</a>, or below:</p> <p>22 April 2013</p> <p>Dear Members of the International Trade committee,</p> <p>We are writing to express our concerns with the proposed trade agreement with the US (TTIP). We invite you to take our concerns into account when voting on the amendments to the draft resolution on the TTIP. </p> <p>In this letter we argue that citizens have a right to openness; that all measures in the agreement have to fully respect our rights enshrined in human rights instruments, including the UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights; that the agreement has to exclude intellectual property rights; and that the Parliament has to step in and defend democracy and the Treaties by excluding investor to state dispute settlement from the agreement.</p> <p><strong>Openness</strong></p> <p>The agreement will mostly attempt to deeply integrate EU and US laws, as the trade tariffs between the EU and US are already low. In our opinion, a deep integration of laws has to take place in public. Negotiations in international organisations show that openness is possible. Citizens have a right to openness. Everyone has the right \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdto take part freely in an active and informed way, and without discrimination, in any important decision-making process that may have an impact on his or her way of life and on his or her rights under article 15, paragraph 1 (a)\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. (ECOSOC, 2009)</p> <p>Companies will have access to the draft texts. In the US hundreds of advisors, many of them corporate lobbyists, are considered cleared advisors. They have access to negotiation documents. (FFII, 2009) The EU does not have an official way of informing companies, but it happens in an unofficial way. (CEO, 2011) The EU can not allow discrimination, which will also create a real risk that the negotiations will lead to a biased result.</p> <p><strong>Human rights</strong></p> <p>According to a leaked version of the Commission&#8217;s draft mandate, (IUST, 2013) the preamble of the agreement will refer to shared values in such areas as human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy and the rule of law. In our opinion, this is not a sufficient safeguard, as the preamble will not be binding. It is also unclear which values are shared. For instance, all EU member states have ratified the UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, while the US did not ratify this covenant. (EP, 2013) Furthermore, regarding human rights, European courts give a wide margin of appreciation to the domestic authorities. The courts only step in and protect human rights in severe cases. If the EU trades away our rights, we are only partially protected. To protect our human rights, all measures in the agreement will have to be balanced themselves. All of them have to fully respect our rights enshrined in human rights instruments, including the UN International Covenant on Economic,<br /> Social and Cultural Rights.</p> <p><strong>Intellectual property</strong></p> <p>There is a deep divide in our societies over intellectual property rights. Exclusive rights on knowledge and culture harm access to knowledge and culture. This threatens health, food security and diffusion of green technology. Furthermore, before people had computers, it took an effort to infringe copyright; now, a mouse click is often enough. The internet made all of us infringers, this threatens our civil rights. It is essential to rethink copyright. In the software field, all developers may be infringers, as there are many trivial and over broad patents. It is also essential to rethink patent law. Trade agreements are not the right forum for this. The agreement has to exclude intellectual property rights, see the declaration signed by over 45 organisations: IP out of TAFTA. (PC, 2013)</p> <p><strong>Investor to state dispute settlement</strong></p> <p>An investor to state dispute settlement mechanism would create international arbitration tribunals above our high court and our human rights court. Multinationals will be able to sue the EU and its member states before such tribunals if changes in law threaten to make their profits lower. This would create a real risk to democracy, human rights, the public interest and our ability to solve financial crises. (Kelsey and Wallach, 2012; NGOs, 2013; Stiglitz, 2011) Both the EU and the US have strong protection for property, there is no need for international arbitration tribunals.</p> <p>The leaked version of the Commission&#8217;s draft mandate rightfully notes that the agreement should not harm the EU\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and member states\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd right to adopt measures necessary to pursue legitimate public policy objectives. But the Commission does not draw the logical conclusion that arbitration tribunals should not be the forums to decide whether the EU&#8217;s policy objectives are legitimate. In fact, the Commission wants to grant these ad hoc tribunals the power to take such essential decisions regarding the competence of the EU, decisions which are in essence constitutional decisions. The Commission&#8217;s proposal would create, without a change of the Treaties, ad hoc parallel constitutional tribunals, without a possibility to appeal to the EU Court of Justice &#8211; the Union&#8217;s \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdconstitutional\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd court. It would be a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcoup d&#8217;\ufffd\ufffdtat\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd against the Union, on behalf of multinationals. In our opinion, the Parliament has to step in and defend democracy and the Treaties by excluding investor to state dispute settlement from the agreement. Disagreement with the US over the interpretation of a ratified agreement can be solved by carefully designed state to state dispute settlement.</p> <p>Yours sincerely,</p> <p>Ante Wessels</p> <p>Foundation for a Free Information Infrastructure (FFII)</p> <p>References</p> <p>CEO (2011), <a href="http://corporateeurope.org/sites/default/files/attachments/lawsuit_backgrounder.pdf">http://corporateeurope.org/sites/default/files/attachments/lawsuit_backgrounder.pdf<br /> </a></p> <p>ECOSOC (2009), Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, General comment No. 21, Right of everyone to take part in cultural life (art. 15, para. 1 (a), of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights), E/C.12/GC/21, <a href="http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm">http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm</a></p> <p>EP (2013), Question for written answer <a href="http://icg.greens-efa.eu/pipermail/hub/2013-March/000047.html">http://icg.greens-efa.eu/pipermail/hub/2013-March/000047.html</a></p> <p>FFII (2009) <a href="http://action.ffii.org/acta/Analysis?action=AttachFile&#038;do=get&#038;target=FFII-Ombudsman-06-2009.pdf">http://action.ffii.org/acta/Analysis?action=AttachFile&#038;do=get&#038;target=FFII-Ombudsman-06-2009.pdf</a></p> <p>IUST (2013), <a href="http://www.s2bnetwork.org/fileadmin/dateien/downloads/EU_Draft_Mandate_-_Inside_US_Trade.pdf">http://www.s2bnetwork.org/fileadmin/dateien/downloads/EU_Draft_Mandate_-_Inside_US_Trade.pdf</a></p> <p>Kelsey and Wallach, 2012,  &#8220;Investor-State&#8221; US trade agreement (TAFTA / TTIP). There are 198 amendments, on many subjects, like intellectual property out (especially from amendment 114), others aim at stronger IP, investor &#8211; state dispute resolution out (amendments 163, 164), more transparency. Some mention ACTA.</p> <p><a href="http://www.europarl.europa.eu/meetdocs/2009_2014/organes/inta/inta_20130424_0900.htm">http://www.europarl.europa.eu/meetdocs/2009_2014/organes/inta/inta_20130424_0900.htm</a><br /> agenda at the top, amendments at the bottom.</p> <p>See also Issues with EU draft mandate for the EU \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd US trade agreement<br /> <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1773">http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1773</a></p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">Text of trade agreement with Singapore will be published before the summer</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1822"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1822</id>   <updated>2013-04-15T16:26:47+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Last week I wrote that <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1819">the trade agreement with Singapore will be secret until it enters into force</a>. The statement was based on an email from EU Trade Spokesperson John Clancy. It turns out this is not correct, the text will be published before the summer. </p> <p>When I first contacted Mr Clancy, the FFII email server was down. I used a personal email address. I asked: </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;On 16 December the EU and Singapore completed final negotiations on a free trade agreement (FTA) between the European Union and Singapore. I can not find the text of the FTA on the Commission&#8217;s website. Did the Commission publish the text, could I receive the text?&#8221;</p></blockquote> <p>Mr Clancy answered: </p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;Political negotiations were completed in December 2012 between the Commissioner and the Singapore Minister \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the &#8216;handshake&#8217; moment if you will.</p> <p>However, there is between 18 months and 2 years of European institutional and democratic process to go through (from translating all the texts into all official EU languages, &#8216;legal scrubbing&#8217; (checking of the texts by lawyer/linguists), signature of the Council (i.e. the Member States) before the agreed text can go before the European Parliament for a final &#8216;Yes/No&#8217; vote. Only if there is a positive &#8216;yes&#8217; vote by the EP does the agreement come into force and the text becomes &#8216;legal&#8217; and is published.</p> <p>We only wish \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd here at the Commission \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd that the time period could be shorter but it is out of our hands I am afraid.</p> <p>So, unfortunately the text is not available yet.&#8221; </p></blockquote> <p>Today I had a phone call with Mr Clancy. He said that he had thought I was an ordinary citizen. So he had just given me a &#8220;snap explanation&#8221;, he summarized a complex process. If he would have known I was involved with an organisation, he would have been more accurate.</p> <p>As I had simply asked whether I could receive the text, a correct answer could have been: &#8220;After legal verification we will publish the text on the website.&#8221;</p> <p>Mr Clancy today said that the text will be published before the summer. I promised to publish his more accurate answer:</p> <blockquote><p>&#8220;Following our telephone conversation earlier today, please allow me to clarify my earlier email to you. The negotiations for the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement were completed in December 2012 in Singapore. This draft text is now progressing through the EU institutional process. This means that the draft text is currently undergoing legal checks or &#8216;legal scrubbing&#8217; by the legal teams from both sides. When this is completed, the draft text will be initialled after which we intend to rapidly publish the text of the draft agreement on the DG trade website. The draft text will then be translated into all EU languages. The next step in the process is the formal European Commission endorsement of the draft agreement. Afterwards, the Council of the EU will be formally asked to approve the agreement. Finally, the draft text will then be voted upon by Members of the European Parliament in Plenary Session at a time of their choosing. Only if there is a &#8216;positive vote&#8217; by the European Parliament does the text become &#8216;legal&#8217; and valid.  The Free Trade Agreement then enters into force after its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. It was this formal publication of the final text I had in mind when we had initially been in contact. But as mentioned, the draft text will be made publicly available much earlier.</p> <p>Thank you for the opportunity to provide this clarification to your organisation.&#8221;</p> </blockquote></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">Trade agreement with Singapore secret until it enters into force</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1819"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1819</id>   <updated>2013-04-12T12:36:06+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p><strong>Update: <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1822">Text of trade agreement with Singapore will be published before the summer<br /> </a><br /> </strong></p> <p>==========================================================</p> <p>(<a href="http://press.ffii.org/Trade%20agreement%20with%20Singapore%20secret%20until%20it%20enters%20into%20force">FFII press release</a>) Text also below:</p> <p><strong>Brussels, 12 April 2013 &#8212; The EU Commission decided to keep the trade agreement with Singapore secret until it enters into force. With this decision the Commission betrays European citizens and democracy, according to the Foundation for a Free Information Infrastructure (FFII).<br /> </strong></p> <p>In December 2012 EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht and Singapore&#8217;s Minister of Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang completed final negotiations on a free trade agreement between the European Union and Singapore. The FFII wanted to analyse whether the text of the agreement is compatible with human rights enshrined in the UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. The FFII noted the Commission had not published the text and asked where it could be found.</p> <p>EU Trade Spokesperson John Clancy wrote the FFII: <em>&#8220;Only if there is a positive &#8216;yes&#8217; vote by the EP does the agreement come into force and the text becomes &#8216;legal&#8217; and is published.&#8221;</em></p> <p>European and Singaporean citizens will not be able to scrutinize the text and provide input to parliaments. It will not be possible to make a human rights impact assessment. Parliaments will not be able to openly discuss the agreement, they will have to adopt or reject a secret text. </p> <p>FFII analyst Ante Wessels: <em>&#8220;The European Parliament overwhelmingly voted down the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) after citizens pointed out it would violate their human rights. This time the Commission hopes to have a &#8216;better result&#8217; by keeping the text secret until it enters into force. This is nothing less than an assault on democracy. Without democracy, the union becomes an empire led by technocrats, disregarding human rights. The union is entering a dark era.&#8221;</em></p> <p><strong>Letter EU Trade Spokesperson John Clancy to FFII</strong></p> <p>&#8220;Political negotiations were completed in December 2012 between the Commissioner and the Singapore Minister \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the &#8216;handshake&#8217; moment if you will.</p> <p>However, there is between 18 months and 2 years of European institutional and democratic process to go through (from translating all the texts into all official EU languages, &#8216;legal scrubbing&#8217; (checking of the texts by lawyer/linguists), signature of the Council (i.e. the Member States) before the agreed text can go before the European Parliament for a final &#8216;Yes/No&#8217; vote. Only if there is a positive &#8216;yes&#8217; vote by the EP does the agreement come into force and the text becomes &#8216;legal&#8217; and is published.</p> <p>We only wish \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd here at the Commission \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd that the time period could be shorter but it is out of our hands I am afraid.</p> <p>So, unfortunately the text is not available yet.&#8221;</p>  <entry>   <title type="html">Issues with EU draft mandate for the EU \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd US trade agreement</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1773"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1773</id>   <updated>2013-03-30T21:34:14+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Inside U.S. Trade obtained the draft EU mandate for the EU &#8211; US trade agreement (TTIP / TAFTA) (<a href="http://www.s2bnetwork.org/fileadmin/dateien/downloads/EU_Draft_Mandate_-_Inside_US_Trade.pdf">pdf</a>), this is the proposal the Commission sent to the Council for a mandate to start the negotiations. I note 6 issues here.</p> <p><strong>Copyright and patents</strong></p> <p>The agreement will include intellectual property rights. This is wrong, as there is a deep divide in our societies over intellectual property rights. Exclusive rights on knowledge and culture harm access to knowledge and culture. This threatens health, food security and diffusion of green technology. Furthermore, before people had computers, it took an effort to infringe copyright; now, a mouse click is often enough to infringe it. The internet made all of us infringers. It is essential to rethink copyright. </p> <p>In the software field, all developers may be infringers, as there are many trivial and over broad patents. It is also essential to rethink patent law. Trade agreements are not the right forum for this. See the declaration signed by over 45 organisations: <a href="http://www.citizen.org/IP-out-of-TAFTA">IP out of TAFTA</a>.</p> <p><strong>Human rights</strong></p> <p>The preamble of the agreement will refer to shared values in such areas as human rights, fundamental freedoms, democracy and the rule of law. There are some issues here. First, the preamble will not be binding. Second, which values are shared? <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1767">All EU member states have ratified the UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights</a> (ICESCR), while the US did not ratify this covenant. Do the EU and US have the same or different ideas on economic, social and cultural rights? Finally, European courts give a wide margin of appreciation to the domestic authorities. The courts only step in and protect human rights in severe cases. If the EU trades away our rights, we are only partially protected. </p> <p>The approach proposed by the Commission \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd references in the not binding preamble \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is not sufficient.</p> <p>Strong binding rules in trade agreements are intrusive. Equally strong human rights protection could possibly provide a solution. But the protection is not equally strong. This creates a gap. To protect human rights, all measures in the agreement will have to be balanced themselves. All of them have to fully respect our rights enshrined in human rights instruments, including the <a href="http://www.un-documents.net/icescr.htm">UN International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights</a></p> <p><strong>Openness</strong></p> <p>The trade tariffs between the EU and US are already low. The agreement will mostly attempt to deeply integrate EU and US law. This is highly sensitive and has to be done in public. It is possible to do this in public, it is the way negotiations happen in international organisations. We have a right to openness. Everyone has the right &#8220;to <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1767">take part freely in an active and informed way</a>, and without discrimination, in any important decision-making process that may have an impact on his or her way of life and on his or her rights under article 15, paragraph 1 (a)&#8221; of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.</p> <p>But the negotiations will be secret and the draft negotiation texts will be secret. This is a violation of our rights. Furthermore, companies will have access to the draft texts. In the US hundreds of advisors, many of them corporate lobbyists, are considered cleared advisors (<a href="http://action.ffii.org/acta/Analysis?action=AttachFile&#038;do=get&#038;target=FFII-Ombudsman-06-2009.pdf">pdf</a>). They have access to negotiation documents. The EU does not have an official way of informing companies, but it happens in an unofficial way (<a href="http://corporateeurope.org/sites/default/files/attachments/lawsuit_backgrounder.pdf">pdf</a>). Companies will have a stronger influence on the negotiations than citizens. This creates a real risk that the negotiations will lead to a biased result.</p> <p><strong>Tribunals above our high court</strong></p> <p>The agreement will contain investor to state dispute settlement. This creates international investor tribunals above our high court. Multinationals will be able to sue states if changes in law threaten to make their profits lower. This is nothing less than an <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1721">assault on democracy</a>, human rights and the public interest. Capital controls like in Cyprus? Forbidden. We trade away our ability to solve existential crises. </p> <p>The draft mandate notes that the agreement should not harm the EU\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and member states\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd right to adopt measures necessary to pursue legitimate public policy objectives. This creates a conflict. On the one hand explicit language forbidding certain policy instruments, on the other hand the same policy instruments should be available. The agreement will grant arbitration tribunals the right to solve such conflicts, they will have decisive power on essential questions, which may even be existential questions. We should never allow this, it distorts the separation of powers. No tribunals above our high court, the only court we can entrust with essential and existential questions.</p> <p><strong>The benefits the agreement will bring</strong></p> <p>The draft mandate notes that the agreement could increase the EU&#8217;s national income by up to 86 billion euro. But academics are less certain of this. <a href="http://www.voxeu.org/article/transatlantic-trade-talks-and-economic-policy-research-time-re-tool">Evenett and Stern note</a>: &#8220;Rather, we don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt really know what it will do because trade economists have failed to develop the necessary tools for understanding its impact. It is time for policy analysts to re-tool.&#8221; </p> <p>They also wrote: &#8220;At its best \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd as John Rawls might have put it \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd this is tantamount to commercial policymaking behind the veil of ignorance. Less charitably, this is muddling through \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd with the risk that, in the rush to defend any accord, evidence-based policymaking becomes policy-based evidence making.&#8221;</p> <p>There is a serious risk that because of the euro crisis the EU may be desperate to claim a success, and adopt a trade agreement that brings less than claimed, and damages more than admitted. </p> <p><strong>Policy space</strong></p> <p>The EU needs policy space to rethink copyright and patent law, and also for future legislative improvements in response to changes in technology or policy. A deep integration of laws with the US will take away policy space. Unlike with EU law, changing the rules later on will not be possible.</p> <p>We need to know which steps will be beneficial without being detrimental. We need public debate.</p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">The EU-US trade agreement and obligations under ICESCR</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1767"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1767</id>   <updated>2013-03-21T16:50:34+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Seven members of the European Parliament (Greens/EFA) asked the Commission a <a href="http://icg.greens-efa.eu/pipermail/hub/2013-March/000047.html">question on the proposed EU-US trade agreement</a>.</p> <blockquote><p>The EU is obliged to respect, protect and fulfil the human rights enshrined in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR). The EU&#8217;s obligation results from the constitutional traditions common to the Member States (Article 6(3) TEU), since all EU member states have ratified the ICESCR. The EU must desist from acts and omissions that create a real risk of nullifying or impairing the enjoyment of ICESCR rights (see also Case C-73/08 Bressol and Others).</p> <p>The United States has signed but not ratified the ICESCR.</p> <p>- How will the Commission ensure, during the negotiations of the announced trade agreement with the US, that the ICESCR rights are respected, including the right of everyone &#8220;to take part freely in an active and informed way, and without discrimination, in any important decision-making process that may have an impact on his or her way of life and on his or her rights under article 15, paragraph 1 (a)&#8221;*.</p> <p>*) ECOSOC (2009), Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, General comment No. 21, Right of everyone to take part in cultural life (art. 15, para. 1 (a), of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights), E/C.12/GC/21, <a href="http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm">http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm</a></p></blockquote></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name> Court judgment on ACTA secrecy is a disservice to democracy</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1761"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1761</id>   <updated>2013-03-20T14:57:12+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>The General Court of the European Court of Justice gave a<a href="http://curia.europa.eu/juris/document/document.jsf?doclang=EN&amp;text=&amp;pageIndex=0&amp;part=1&amp;mode=DOC&amp;docid=135225&amp;occ=first&amp;dir=&amp;cid=23074"> judgment in Case T\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd301/10</a>, In \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt Veld against European Commission about transparency of ACTA documents, 19 March 2013.</p> <p>The Court upholds the secrecy in general, and only finds regarding a few documents that the secrecy was wrong.</p> <p>The Court considers &#8220;that public participation in the procedure relating to the negotiation and the conclusion of an international agreement is necessarily restricted.&#8221; (paragraph 120)</p> <p>The Court agrees with the Commission that secrecy is necessary: &#8220;As the Commission emphasises, establishing and protecting a sphere of mutual trust in the context of international relations is a very delicate exercise.&#8221; (paragraph 126)</p> <p>The Court overlooks many examples of international organisations where negotiations take place with much more openness and input from civil society.</p> <p>The Court disregards that multinationals do have access to negotiation texts.</p> <p>The Court disregards that meaningful debates in parliaments are impossible this way.</p> <p>The Court disregards that scrutiny gives a higher quality.</p> <p>In paragraph 181 the Court considers &#8220;Moreover, and quite incidentally, it should be noted that the conduct of negotiations for the conclusion of an international agreement falls, in principle, within the domain of the executive (in \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt Veld v Council, paragraph 120 above, paragraph 88) and that those negotiations do not in any way prejudice the public debate that may develop once the international agreement is signed, in the context of the ratification procedure.&#8221;</p> <p>Trade agreements have many chapters and may have a total of a 1000 pages, are presented as deals that will make us all richer. The pressure to say yes is enormous.</p> <p>With this judgment, the Court disregards article 1 Treaty on European Union (TEU): &#8220;(&#8230;) This Treaty marks a new stage in the process of creating an ever closer union among the peoples of Europe, in which decisions are taken as openly as possible and as closely as possible to the citizen.&#8221;</p> <p>The Court disregards the right of everyone \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdto take part freely in an active and informed way, and without discrimination, in any important decision-making process that may have an impact on his or her way of life and on his or her rights under article 15, paragraph 1 (a)\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. (ECOSOC, 2009)</p> <p>We live in a union with a democratic deficit. Rigorous openness would help. The Court says no to that.</p> <p>The Court&#8217;s judgment is a disservice to democracy.</p> <p>&#8212;-<br /> ECOSOC (2009), UN Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, General comment No. 21, Right of everyone to take part in cultural life (art. 15, para. 1 (a), of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights), E/C.12/GC/21, <a href="http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm">http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cescr/comments.htm</a></p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">Do not turn TAFTA into ACTA v2.0</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1743"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1743</id>   <updated>2013-03-18T13:59:58+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Today, more than 35 European and United States civil society organisations <a href="http://www.citizen.org/IP-out-of-TAFTA">released this declaration</a>: </p> <p><strong>IP OUT OF TAFTA</strong></p> <p>Last year, millions of Americans told their government not to undermine the open internet. We sent the SOPA and PIPA bills down to defeat.  </p> <p>Soon after, hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets of Europe to protest against ACTA, a secretive trade agreement that would have violated our rights online and chilled generic drug competition. </p> <p>Meanwhile, leaked trade texts revealed US and EU threats to access to affordable medicines, which significantly disrupted trade talks in India and the Pacific.</p> <p>On February 13, the US President Barack Obama, the European Council President Herman Van Rompuy, and the European Commission President Jos\ufffd\ufffd Manuel Barroso announced the official launch of negotiations of a Transatlantic Free Trade Agreement (TAFTA)\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdalso touted as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, or TTIP. </p> <p>We, the undersigned, are internet freedom and public health groups, activists, and other public interest leaders dedicated to the rights of all people to access cultural and educational resources and affordable medicines, to enjoy a free and open internet, and to benefit from open and needs-driven innovation.</p> <p>First, we insist that the European Union and United States release, in timely and ongoing fashion, any and all negotiating or pre-negotiation texts. We believe that secretive &#8220;trade&#8221; negotiations are absolutely unacceptable forums for devising binding rules that change national non-trade laws.</p> <p>Second, we insist that the proposed TAFTA exclude any provisions related to patents, copyright, trademarks, data protection, geographical indications, or other forms of so-called &#8220;intellectual property&#8221;. Such provisions could impede our rights to health, culture, and free expression and otherwise affect our daily lives.</p> <p>Past trade agreements negotiated by the US and EU have significantly increased the privileges of multinational corporations at the expense of society in general. Provisions in these agreements can, among many other concerns, limit free speech, constrain access to educational materials such as textbooks and academic journals, and, in the case of medicines, raise healthcare costs and contribute to preventable suffering and death. </p> <p>Unless &#8220;intellectual property&#8221; is excluded from these talks, we fear that the outcome will be an agreement that inflicts the worst of both regimes\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd rules on the other party. From a democratic perspective, we believe that important rules governing technology, health, and culture should be debated in the US Congress, the European Parliament, national parliaments, and other transparent forums where all stakeholders can be heard\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnot in closed negotiations that give privileged access to corporate insiders.</p> <p>The TAFTA negotiations must not lead to a rewriting of patent and copyright rules in a way that tilts the balance even further away from the interests of citizens.  </p> <p><a href="http://www.citizen.org/IP-out-of-TAFTA">IP OUT OF TAFTA</a></p> <p>From the FFII press release:</p> <blockquote><p> FFII analyst Ante Wessels: &#8220;The industry already dreams of setting a gold standard in areas such as intellectual property rights protection. Does that sound familiar? Yes, it does. It sounds like ACTA, the agreement overwhelmingly voted down last July in the European Parliament. ACTA was, in almost all aspects, a drama, out of touch with our societies. Trade agreements are not the right forum to discuss intellectual property rights.&#8221; </p></blockquote> <p>The FFII regarding transparency:</p> <blockquote><p>On average, the trade tariffs between the EU and the US  are already low (under 3%). To enlarge trade, progress will have to come  from a deep integration of EU and US laws. In 2010, the EU Ombudsman agreed with the FFII that citizens have a clear interest in being informed about agreements that make it necessary for the EU to change laws. </p> <p>FFII analyst Ante EDRi wrote the draft resolution supported &#8220;a ban on &#8216;all forms of pornography&#8217; (paragraph 17), with online policing being done by private companies (paragraph 14)&#8221;. See <a href="http://www.edri.org/porn_ban">EDRi&#8217;s excellent post for the background</a>.</p> <p>The Parliament rejected paragraph 14 about online policing being done by private companies.</p> <p>The Parliament rejected the second half of paragraph 17. Paragraph 17 now reads: &#8220;Calls on the EU and its Member States to take concrete action on its resolution of 16 September 1997 on discrimination against women in advertising.&#8221;</p> <p>The resolution adopted yesterday refers to the 1997 &#8220;<a href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:51997IP0258:EN:HTML">Resolution on discrimination against women in advertising</a>&#8220;, which contains:</p> <p>&#8220;5. Calls for statutory measures to prevent any form of pornography in the media and in advertising and for a ban on advertising for pornographic products and sex tourism;&#8221;</p> <p>Strangely, point 5 of the 1997 resolution goes beyond the scope of that resolution (beyond advertising). The 1997 resolution also mentions New Media, including the Internet (considerations L to N).</p> <p>Yesterday&#8217;s resolution calls to take concrete steps on the earlier resolution, which called for statutory measures to prevent any form of pornography in the media. In a somewhat covert way, the Parliament asked for statutory measures to prevent any form of pornography in the media, arguably including the Internet.</p> <p>What resolution will the Parliament adopt 15 years from now? Concrete steps on the 2013 resolution?</p> <p><strong>Update:</strong> <a href="http://www.edri.org/edrigram/number11.5/porn-parliament-politics">EDRi writes about the debate</a>: &#8220;Actually, it turns out that this was not the intention at all. During the debate, Kartika Liotard, the Parliamentarian that proposed that particular text, made it clear that she didn&#8217;t mean the proposal to be taken seriously. Instead it is simply meant to draw attention to the issues at stake.&#8221;</p> <p><a href="https://twitter.com/EDRi_org/status/311452410721738753">98 Members of parliament abstained</a> in the final vote on the report as a whole. She got her attention, but less votes. The report would have gotten more support if paragraph 17 would have been fully deleted. Jan Albrecht: &#8220;Only first part of para. 17 is still in as a general reference to the 1997 resolution. That is <a href="https://twitter.com/JanAlbrecht/status/311451261285326849">why Greens abstained in the end</a>.&#8221;</p> <p>EDRi notes a positive development: &#8220;These two votes represent a change of approach from the European Parliament. Whereas it voted at the beginning of the current term of office for more online policing (in the Gallo report) by internet intermediaries, the Parliament has now twice voted, by a significant majority, in plenary session against this approach.&#8221;</p> <p>See also <a href="http://falkvinge.net/2013/03/12/european-parliament-just-voted-to-ban-porn-but-limits-scope-to-advertising-following-protests-and-hides-who-voted-for-it/">Falkvinge</a>.</p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry xml:lang="fr">   <title type="html">Merci Peter Drahos with John Braithwaite</title>   <link href="http://renemages.wordpress.com/2013/03/01/merci-peter-drahos-with-john-braithwaite/"/>   <id>http://renemages.wordpress.com/?p=2481</id>   <updated>2013-03-01T09:09:03+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><p><a href="http://renemages.wordpress.com/2013/03/01/merci-peter-drahos/peterdrahos/" rel="attachment wp-att-2489"><img src="http://renemages.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/peterdrahos.png?w=490" alt="PeterDrahos" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2489" /></a></p> <blockquote><p> &quot;Propping up the patent system and other intellectual property systems at the expense of free trade turned out to be something of a long-run miscalculation by states. From <a href="http://www.cnas.org/files/documents/publications/CNAS_WCIT_commentary.pdf">an analysis of Alexander Klimburg on the ITU WCIT</a> summit for a ITRs revision:</p> <blockquote><p> According to noted Internet governance scholar Wolfgang Kleinw\ufffd\ufffdchter, the language in the new ITRs could actually imply the creation of a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnew\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd multistakeholder system for Internet governance, one that ultimately replaces the existing system with something working under the aegis and ultimate control of the ITU.</p></blockquote> <p>There are quite a few academics that tried to transform the ITU into a multi-stakeholder governance mechanism. But the reformist approach overlooks in the difficulties of a world organisation as the ITU. The article of Klimburg compares a clash between &#8220;Cybersovereignty&#8221; and &#8220;Multistakeholder&#8221; at the WCIT to the Yalta meeting. </p> <p>The article of Klimburg overlooks that ITU-T is a multistakeholder organisation and European players embark on a cybersovereignty approach, simply because the multistakeholderism of the US does not give them a fair share, still they cannot support an expansion of power for ITU world governance: In a world with more than 200 nations &#8220;world governance&#8221; leads to hypocrite political corruption, nurtures a political class that at best trickles down the &#8220;capacity building and technical assistance&#8221; in their nation. There is simply no reason why leading industrial nations would want to let questionable regimes of nations with an irrelevant internet share meddle with the governance of the internet. And also you hardly discover good reason why the expensive closed-shop ITU-T multistakeholderism or the IGF would seem qualified. The US excitement for flat multistakeholder governance was build on an engineer perspective of the kind &#8220;railways to the railway people&#8221; along libertarian scepticism against the US government capabilities to get it right. rises?</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1724"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1724</id>   <updated>2013-02-05T13:18:07+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Today EU trade commissioner Karel de Gucht <a href="http://www.europolitics.info/external-policies/de-gucht-aims-to-wrap-up-transatlantic-trade-talks-before-summit-art347575-46.html">travels to Washington</a> to discuss the possibilities to start negotiations on an EU &#8211; US trade agreement. Some companies already dream of <a href="http://seenthis.net/messages/106809">setting a gold standard in areas such as intellectual property rights (IPR) protection</a>. That sounds like ACTA, the agreement overwhelmingly voted down last July in the European Parliament. Will ACTA return, should IPR be part of a Trans Atlantic &#8220;Free Trade&#8221; Agreement (TAFTA)? Opinions go from in, out or optional. The right answer is out, as with an IPR chapter, the EU and US will violate their human rights obligations. </p> <p><strong>IPR in or out?</strong></p> <p>The June 2012 interim report of the EU-U.S. High Level Working Group on Jobs and Growth said about inclusion of IPR in an EU &#8211; US trade agreement: &#8220;Both sides agree that it would not be feasible in negotiations to seek to reconcile across the board differences in the IPR obligations that each typically includes in its comprehensive trade agreements.&#8221; (<a href="http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/html/149557.htm">pdf</a>)</p> <p>The EU and US then held consultations, <a href="http://infojustice.org/archives/28254">Infojustice lists some reactions</a> regarding IPR. The National Association of Manufacturers, National Foreign Trade Council and a Joint comment by the Pharmaceutical manufacturers and Research Association, and the European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations are in favor of including IPR in the trade agreement. The European Generic Medicines Association and the the (US) Generic Pharmaceutical Association recommend keeping IPR out of the trade agreement. </p> <p>In its submission, the National Foreign Trade Council mentions &#8220;a comprehensive agreement or set of agreements&#8221;. A set of agreements would be the right approach, as one yes or no vote on a monolithic trade agreement<a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1719"> does not seem compatible with democracy</a>. </p> <p><strong>An optional IPR chapter?</strong></p> <p>Intellectual Property Watch yesterday reported the <a href="http://www.ip-watch.org/2013/02/04/push-for-eu-us-fta-could-restart-discussions-about-iprs/">possibility that an IPR chapter could be made optional</a>: &#8220;Being part of a larger, comprehensive package, special provisions in the IP chapter might not be made a make-or-break issue for a TAFTA, unlike in the debates about the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement.&#8221;</p> <p>That, at first sight, may look reasonable. But it is important to remember what Michael Geist wrote in his report on ACTA for the European Parliament International Trade committee: &#8220;In an attempt to resolve ongoing conflicts over several substantive areas, the ACTA negotiators agreed to make many provisions permissive rather than mandatory. Supporters frequently point to the non-mandatory nature of several contentious provisions as evidence that there is little reason for concern with the substantive elements of ACTA. The permissive approach may be a useful mechanism to achieve consensus, but it provides cold comfort to those concerned with the long-term implications of the agreement. The experience with other treaties indicates that flexible, permissive language is gradually transformed into mandatory, best-practice language.&#8221; (<a href="http://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/nl/studiesdownload.html?languageDocument=EN&#038;file=73311">pdf</a>)</p> <p><strong>IPR out</strong></p> <p>Access to knowledge and culture is a human right. As <a href="http://ssrn.com/abstract=1926102">Peter Yu wrote earlier</a>, it is imperative that countries strike a more appropriate balance between the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights and the commitments made in international or regional human rights instruments.</p> <p>An optional IPR chapter will point in the wrong direction. All countries have an obligation to respect, protect and fulfil human rights, and must desist from acts and omissions that create a real risk of nullifying or impairing these rights. All countries are obliged to create an enabling environment conducive to the universal fulfilment of human rights. (See the Maastricht Principles on Extraterritorial Obligations of States in the area of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, <a href="http://www.ciel.org/Publications/Maastricht_ETO_Principles_21Oct11.pdf">pdf</a>)</p> <p>With an IPR chapter, the EU and US will violate their human rights obligations. </p> <p>Earlier posts:<br /> <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1719">The era of monolithic trade agreements is over?</a><br /> <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1721">EU \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd US trade agreement will give a boost to expropriation trolls</a> </p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">EU \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd US trade agreement will give a boost to expropriation trolls</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1721"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1721</id>   <updated>2013-02-04T16:25:42+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Tomorrow EU trade commissioner Karel de Gucht will <a href="http://www.europolitics.info/external-policies/de-gucht-aims-to-wrap-up-transatlantic-trade-talks-before-summit-art347575-46.html">travel to Washington</a> to discuss the possibilities to start negotiations on an EU &#8211; US trade agreement. The industry already dreams of setting <a href="http://seenthis.net/messages/106809">a gold standard in areas such as intellectual property protection</a> &#8211; just like they tried with ACTA. But that is not all. An EU &#8211; US trade agreement will also give a boost to expropriation trolls, the more evil kid brothers of patent and copyright trolls. Expropriation trolls abuse arbitration tribunals to attack legislative reforms and demand high damages.</p> <p><strong>Investor &#8211; state arbitration</strong></p> <p>The Interim Report to Leaders from the Co-Chairs EU-U.S. High Level Working Group on Jobs and Growth, 19 June 2012, (<a href="http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/html/149557.htm">pdf</a>) writes about a possible investment chapter: &#8220;The aim would be to negotiate investment liberalisation and protection provisions on the basis of the highest levels of liberalisation and protection that both sides have negotiated to date.&#8221;</p> <p>The High Level Working Group refers to investor &#8211; state arbitration, which gives multinational companies the right to directly sue states in international tribunals. Adding investor &#8211; state arbitration to an EU &#8211; US agreement is not necessary, but detrimental. </p> <p>Not necessary: Both the EU and US have excellent laws providing protection against expropriation. Both the EU and US have good court systems and highly respected high courts. We are not banana republics. There is no need for protection against expropriation in a trade agreement between the EU and US. </p> <p>Detrimental: Arbitration tribunals are placed above the high courts. There is almost no possibility for appeal. In recent years, arbitration tribunals increasingly stretched the concept of expropriation. Multinationals claim that reforms of legislation that could reduce their profits are expropriation and demand high damages. Arbitration tribunals award such damages. Basically, investor &#8211; state arbitration is hijacked by a captive incrowd. </p> <p>Public Citizen&#8217;s Lori Wallach wrote a two part overview (<a href="http://acta.ffii.org/ http://kluwerarbitrationblog.com/blog/2013/01/07/brewing-storm-over-isdr-clouds-trans-pacific-partnership-talks-part-i/">part I</a>, <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/ http://kluwerarbitrationblog.com/blog/2013/01/14/brewing-storm-over-isdr-clouds-trans-pacific-partnership-talks-part-ii/">part II</a>) of investor &#8211; state arbitration in the TPP agreement, which is also an excellent general overview. See also the <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/ http://press.ffii.org/Press%20releases/CETA%20threatens%20Internet%2C%20health%20and%20democracy">FFII press release on the EU &#8211; Canada trade agreement</a>. </p> <p><strong>Assault on democracy</strong></p> <p>Faced with the negative consequences of investor &#8211; state arbitration, Australia decided not to sign treaties containing such clauses any more. The High Level Working Group disregards recent developments, its advice is flawed and dangerous.</p> <p>Patent and copyright trolls are legal entities that use bogus law suits to extort money. They use flaws in legislation, legislation that can still be repaired. Expropriation trolls use arbitration tribunals to attack legislative reforms and protect old business models. With investor &#8211; state arbitration we undermine democracy and risk making trolling perpetual.</p> <p>Yesterday: <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1719">The era of monolithic trade agreements is over?</a><br /> Tomorrow: A new ACTA?</p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">The era of monolithic trade agreements is over?</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1719"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1719</id>   <updated>2013-02-03T18:00:32+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>Tuesday EU trade commissioner Karel de Gucht will <a href="http://acta.ffii.org/ http://www.europolitics.info/external-policies/de-gucht-aims-to-wrap-up-transatlantic-trade-talks-before-summit-art347575-46.html">travel to Washington</a> to discuss the possibilities to start negotiations on an EU &#8211; US trade agreement. The industry already dreams of <a href="http://seenthis.net/messages/106809">setting a gold standard in areas such as intellectual property protection</a>. Does that sound familiar? Yes, it does. It sounds like ACTA, the agreement overwhelmingly voted down last July in the European Parliament. </p> <p>ACTA was, in almost all aspects, a drama, out of touch with our societies. In a series of posts on this blog, I will give some thoughts on how to do things better. Today: the era of monolithic trade agreements is over?</p> <p>Rewriting our laws in secrecy</p> <p>On average, the trade tariffs between the EU and the US are already low (under 3%). To enlarge trade, progress will have to come from the tackling of non-tariff barriers. The EU commission calls them <a href="http://ec.europa.eu/trade/creating-opportunities/bilateral-relations/countries/united-states/">behind the border regulatory restrictions</a>. Such behind the border regulatory restrictions are, in plain words, our laws. We will have to rewrite our laws to enlarge trade with the US. </p> <p>There will be tough choices to make. As <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/11/us-usa-eu-trade-idUSBRE8BA05Y20121211">Reuters explains</a>, a &#8220;trade deal could be a lot for Europe to swallow&#8221;: &#8220;Can Europeans, who have balked for years at many U.S. food imports, accept a free trade agreement with the United States that opens the door for imports of genetically modified crops and chickens cleaned with chlorine?&#8221; See also Glyn Moody, <a href="http://blogs.computerworlduk.com/open-enterprise/2013/01/after-acta-tap-the-trans-atlantic-partnership-agreement/index.htm">After ACTA: Trans-Atlantic Partnership Agreement</a>.</p> <p>The point I want to make here, is that the trade negotiators will discuss changing our laws behind closed doors. Only company lobbyists and some members of parliaments will have access to the negotiation texts. The outcome will be one big package, say 1000 pages, to be voted in one vote, yes or no. The EU is in a dire state, the commission desperately wants a success. The pressure on the European Parliament to vote yes will be huge. What will happen will not be a feast of democracy.</p> <p>A deep integration of our laws, negotiated in secrecy, with only access to some, voted in once, is not compatible with democracy &#8211; even if the final vote is an open parliamentary vote. </p> <p>We can do better. On some issues, the EU and US will be able to reach agreement rather easily. There is no need for secrecy here. Negotiate and conclude a light agreement. This can be done without delay.</p> <p>On other issues, agreement will be much harder to reach. As these are sensitive issues, secrecy is unacceptable here. The negotiators will have to discuss these issues in the open. They can then present them to parliaments in the smallest possible balanced chunks. This will provide a much higher legitimacy. The Lisbon Treaty makes this possible. Democracy necessitates that the era of monolithic trade agreements is over.</p> <p>Tomorrow, the second blog, on expropriation trolls.</p></content>   <author>    <name>FFII ACTA Blog</name>    <uri>http://acta.ffii.org</uri>   </author>   <source>    <title type="html">Blog</title>    <subtitle type="html">An information service from the FFII e.V. working group on ACTA</subtitle>    <link rel="self" href="http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2"/>    <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?feed=rss2</id>    <updated>2013-11-17T19:10:07+00:00</updated>   </source>  </entry>   <entry>   <title type="html">CETA threatens Internet, health and democracy</title>   <link href="http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1707"/>   <id>http://acta.ffii.org/?p=1707</id>   <updated>2013-01-31T09:24:14+00:00</updated>   <content type="html"><div class="images"></div><p>The draft trade agreement between the European Union and Canada (CETA) threatens the Internet, health and democracy. The agreement contains an investor-state arbitration clause, which gives multinational companies the right to directly sue states in international tribunals. CETA places these arbitration tribunals above the high courts of Europe and Canada.</p> <p>(-> <a href="http://www.ffii.fr/CETA-menace-internet-la-sante-et-la-democratie?lang=fr">Version Fran\ufffd\ufffdaise</a>)</p> <p>Bypass democracy</p> <p>Investor-state arbitration clauses give multinationals the right to sue countries if they dislike legislative changes. Tobacco company Philip Morris sued Australia over the Tobacco Plain Packaging Bill, which introduced restrictions on the use of cigarette company&#8217;s logos on cigarette packets and allow for more space for health warnings. After Australia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds High Court dismissed the legal challenge, Philip Morris launched an investor-state case. As a result, Australia decided not to sign treaties with investor-state arbitration clauses any more.</p> <p>The EU and Canada have been negotiating the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) since 2009. Negotiations took place behind closed doors, the draft texts are still secret. The <a href="http://www.bilaterals.org/spip.php?article22593">website bilaterals.org</a> and Kriton Arsenis, a member of the European Parliament Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, revealed the existence of the investor-state arbitration clause. Arsenis <a href="http://www.neurope.eu/blog/arbitration-clause-eu-canada-trade-agreement">criticizes the arbitration clause as an easy way to bypass democracy</a>.</p> <p><strong>Conflicts of Interest</strong></p> <p>Multinationals see reform of legislation that could reduce their profits as expropriation and demand high damages. In recent years, arbitration tribunals increasingly stretched the concept of expropriation. Lawyers advise multinationals in setting up investment structures, and these same attorneys and their office colleagues also act as arbitrators in tribunals. This gives rise to conflicts of interest.</p> <p><strong>Block Reforms</strong></p> <p>The arbitration clause will have a negative impact on innovation and the Internet. The trade agreement with Canada will allow multinational companies to attack legislative reforms and protect old business models. This endangers reform of copyright and patent law.</p> <p>The Internet suffers from an excessive enforcement of an outdated copyright. Filtering, blocking and banning links hamper the functioning of the Internet. CETA will give multinationals the possibility to thwart necessary reforms.</p> <p><strong>Agenda</strong></p> <p>EU trade commissioner <a href="http://www.europolitics.info/external-policies/de-gucht-aims-to-wrap-up-transatlantic-trade-talks-before-summit-art347575-46.html">Karel De Gucht will visit Canada on 6 February</a> 2013 in the hope of concluding the trade talks. Yes.</p> <p>First, access to knowledge and culture is a human right. As Peter Yu wrote earlier, it is imperative that countries strike a more appropriate balance between the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights and the commitments made in international or regional human rights instruments.
